Northern Cardinal.description: The Northern Cardinal is a fairly large, long-tailed songbird with a short, very thick bill and a prominent crest. Cardinals often sit with a hunched-over posture and with the tail pointed straight down.
Northern Cardinal.habitat: Woodlands, gardens, shrublands, and urban areas.
Northern Cardinal.nesting: They typically build their nests in dense shrubs or small trees.

American Robin.description: The American Robin is a large, gray-brown thrush with a rich rust-red breast, and a loud, clear cheer-up, cheerily song.
American Robin.diet: Primarily earthworms and insects, but they also eat berries and fruits.
American Robin.nesting: They build cup-shaped nests made of grass, twigs, and mud, often placed in the crotch of a tree or on a building ledge.

Mallard.description: The Mallard is a large, dabbling duck with a long, broad bill and a distinctive iridescent-green patch on the wing.
Mallard.habitat: Lakes, ponds, rivers, marshes, and coastal habitats.
Mallard.diet: Mainly aquatic vegetation, insects, and small fish.
Mallard.nesting: They build nests lined with down, typically near water.

Bald Eagle.description: The Bald Eagle is a large, powerful bird of prey with a white head and tail contrasting with a dark brown body. Bald Eagles have a wingspan of 6 to 7 feet.
Bald Eagle.habitat: Near large bodies of open water such as lakes, rivers, marshes, and coastal areas.
Bald Eagle.diet: Mainly fish, but they also prey on birds, mammals, and carrion.
Bald Eagle.nesting: They build large nests, called eyries, in tall trees or on cliffs.

Peregrine Falcon.description: The Peregrine Falcon is a large, powerful falcon with a blue-gray back, barred underparts, and a distinctive dark 'mustache' mark on its face.
Peregrine Falcon.habitat: Cliffs, tall buildings, and urban areas.
Peregrine Falcon.diet: Primarily birds, but they also prey on bats and insects.
Peregrine Falcon.nesting: They often nest on cliff ledges or tall buildings, and sometimes use artificial nest boxes.

Blue Jay.description: The Blue Jay is a strikingly colorful bird with bright blue upperparts, a white or light gray underbelly, and a black necklace across the throat and upper chest.
Blue Jay.diet: Mainly nuts, seeds, and insects, but they also eat small vertebrates and eggs.
Blue Jay.nesting: They build bulky cup-shaped nests in trees.

American Crow.description: The American Crow is a large, all-black bird with a sturdy bill and a fan-shaped tail.
American Crow.habitat: Varied habitats including woodlands, fields, parks, and urban areas.
American Crow.diet: Omnivorous, feeding on insects, carrion, small vertebrates, seeds, and fruits.
American Crow.nesting: They build bulky nests made of sticks and twigs, often placed in tall trees.

Ruby-throated Hummingbird.description: The Ruby-throated Hummingbird is a tiny bird with iridescent green upperparts and a bright ruby-red throat patch.
Ruby-throated Hummingbird.diet: Mainly nectar from flowers, supplemented with insects and spiders.
Ruby-throated Hummingbird.nesting: They build cup-shaped nests made of plant material, bound together with spider silk, and camouflaged with lichens.

Great Horned Owl.description: The Great Horned Owl is a large, widespread owl species with prominent ear tufts and piercing yellow eyes.
Great Horned Owl.habitat: Forests, open woodlands, deserts, and urban areas.
Great Horned Owl.diet: Varied, including mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, and large insects.
Great Horned Owl.nesting: They often use abandoned nests of other birds or nest in tree cavities.

Downy Woodpecker.description: The Downy Woodpecker is a small woodpecker with black-and-white plumage and a short bill.
Downy Woodpecker.diet: Mainly insects, but they also eat seeds and berries.
Downy Woodpecker.nesting: They excavate nest cavities in dead branches or tree trunks.

Red-tailed Hawk.description: The Red-tailed Hawk is a large bird of prey with broad wings and a distinctive brick-red tail.
Red-tailed Hawk.habitat: Varied habitats including open country, woodlands, and urban areas.
Red-tailed Hawk.diet: Mainly small mammals, but they also prey on birds, reptiles, and carrion.
Red-tailed Hawk.nesting: They build bulky nests made of sticks, often placed in tall trees.

American Goldfinch.description: The American Goldfinch is a small, brightly colored bird with a yellow body and black wings and cap.
American Goldfinch.habitat: Fields, meadows, gardens, and woodland edges.
American Goldfinch.diet: Mainly seeds, particularly from thistle and other composite plants.
American Goldfinch.nesting: They build cup-shaped nests lined with plant down, often placed in shrubs or trees.

Northern Mockingbird.description: The Northern Mockingbird is a medium-sized songbird with gray plumage and long tail feathers.
Northern Mockingbird.habitat: Varied habitats including woodlands, parks, and urban areas.
Northern Mockingbird.diet: Omnivorous, feeding on insects, fruits, and berries.
Northern Mockingbird.nesting: They build cup-shaped nests made of twigs, grasses, and other plant materials.

Canada Goose.description: The Canada Goose is a large waterfowl species with a black head and neck, white cheeks, and a brown body. It is known for its distinctive honking call and V-shaped flight formation.
Canada Goose.habitat: Lakes, ponds, rivers, marshes, and grassy fields.
Canada Goose.diet: Mainly grasses, sedges, and aquatic plants, but they also eat grains and agricultural crops.
Canada Goose.nesting: They build large nests made of grasses and lined with down, typically near water.

Barn Owl.description: The Barn Owl is a medium-sized owl with a distinctive heart-shaped facial disc and pale plumage. It is known for its silent flight and nocturnal hunting habits.
Barn Owl.habitat: Open fields, grasslands, agricultural areas, and marshes.
Barn Owl.diet: Mainly rodents, but they also prey on small birds, insects, and reptiles.
Barn Owl.nesting: They often nest in barns, abandoned buildings, or cavities in trees, and do not build nests.

Mourning Dove.description: The Mourning Dove is a medium-sized, slender dove with a gray-brown body, pinkish head, and long, pointed tail. It is known for its mournful cooing call.
Mourning Dove.habitat: Woodlands, fields, urban areas, and parks.
Mourning Dove.nesting: They build flimsy nests made of twigs and grasses, often in trees or shrubs.

Great Blue Heron.description: The Great Blue Heron is a large wading bird with a long neck, a dagger-like bill, and gray-blue plumage. It is known for its slow, deliberate movements and impressive hunting skills.
Great Blue Heron.habitat: Marshes, swamps, rivers, lakes, and coastal areas.
Great Blue Heron.diet: Mainly fish, but they also eat amphibians, reptiles, insects, and small mammals.
Great Blue Heron.nesting: They build large stick nests in trees, typically near water.

Black-capped Chickadee.description: The Black-capped Chickadee is a small, non-migratory songbird with a black cap and bib, white cheeks, and grayish body. It is known for its cheerful chick-a-dee-dee-dee call.
Black-capped Chickadee.habitat: Woodlands, forests, parks, and suburban areas.
Black-capped Chickadee.nesting: They excavate cavities in trees or use old woodpecker nests for nesting.

Belted Kingfisher.description: The Belted Kingfisher is a medium-sized bird with a shaggy crest, a blue-gray back, and a distinctive blue and white breast band. It is known for its rattling call and fishing prowess.
Belted Kingfisher.habitat: Rivers, streams, lakes, ponds, and coastal areas.
Belted Kingfisher.diet: Mainly fish, but they also eat crustaceans, insects, and small vertebrates.
Belted Kingfisher.nesting: They excavate burrows in sandy or gravelly banks, often near water.

Budgerigar.description: The Budgerigar, often simply called budgie, is the most common and widely kept species of parakeet.
Budgerigar.plumage: Vibrant green with yellow and black markings on the head and wings.

Monk Parakeet.description: The Monk Parakeet, also known as the Quaker Parrot, is native to South America but has established feral populations in many other parts of the world.

Indian Ringneck Parakeet.description: The Indian Ringneck Parakeet is native to parts of Africa and Asia, including the Indian subcontinent.
Indian Ringneck Parakeet.plumage: Variety of colors including green, blue, yellow, and lutino.

Australian King Parrot.description: The Australian King Parrot is found in forests and woodlands of eastern Australia.
Australian King Parrot.plumage: Vibrant red and green in males, green in females.

Alexandrine Parakeet.description: The Alexandrine Parakeet is native to forests and woodlands of South and Southeast Asia.
Alexandrine Parakeet.plumage: Green with distinctive red beaks and prominent neck rings.

Bourke's Parrot.description: Bourke's Parrot is a small, colorful parakeet native to the arid regions of Australia.
Bourke's Parrot.plumage: Soft pastel colors including pink, peach, and blue.

Lineolated Parakeet.description: The Lineolated Parakeet, also known as the Linnie, is a small parakeet species native to the forests of Central and South America.
Lineolated Parakeet.plumage: Mainly green with dark lines or bars across the body.

Rosy-faced Lovebird.description: The Rosy-faced Lovebird, also known as the Peach-faced Lovebird, is a small parrot native to arid regions of southwestern Africa.
Rosy-faced Lovebird.plumage: Green with a peach-colored face and throat.

Green-cheeked Conure.description: The Green-cheeked Conure, also known as the Green-cheeked Parakeet, is native to South America.
Green-cheeked Conure.plumage: Mainly green with a red belly and blue primary feathers.

Pacific Parrotlet.description: The Pacific Parrotlet is one of the smallest parrot species, native to Central and South America.
Pacific Parrotlet.plumage: Varies from bright green to blue with yellow or green faces in males, duller in females.

Burrowing Parakeet.description: The Burrowing Parakeet, also known as the Patagonian Conure, is native to the grasslands and scrublands of South America.
Burrowing Parakeet.plumage: Mainly green with a blue crown and red-orange belly.

Yellow-chevroned Parakeet.description: The Yellow-chevroned Parakeet is native to tropical South America, including parts of Brazil, Bolivia, and Paraguay.
Yellow-chevroned Parakeet.plumage: Mainly green with yellow patches on the wings and cheeks.

Blue-winged Parrotlet.description: The Blue-winged Parrotlet is native to the forests and woodlands of South America.
Blue-winged Parrotlet.plumage: Mainly green with blue wings and a yellow-green face.

Red-rumped Parrot.description: The Red-rumped Parrot, also known as the Grass Parrot, is native to Australia.
Red-rumped Parrot.plumage: Green with a red rump and blue markings on the wings.

Spectacled Parrotlet.description: The Spectacled Parrotlet is native to the Andean foothills of South America.
Spectacled Parrotlet.plumage: Mainly green with a blue crown and a distinct white eye-ring.

Princess Parrot.description: The Princess Parrot is native to the arid regions of Australia.
Princess Parrot.plumage: Soft pastel green with pink throat and belly, blue crown, and long tail feathers.

Senegal Parrot.description: The Senegal Parrot is native to a wide range of habitats in West Africa.
Senegal Parrot.plumage: Mainly green with a gray head, yellow chest, and orange belly.

Fischer's Lovebird.description: Fischer's Lovebird is native to a small region in east-central Africa.
Fischer's Lovebird.plumage: Mainly green with orange face, chest, and upper back, and blue rump and tail.

Golden-mantled Racquet-tail.description: The Golden-mantled Racquet-tail is native to the forests of the Philippines.
Golden-mantled Racquet-tail.plumage: Mainly green with a golden-yellow mantle on the back, and blue tail feathers.

Turquoise Parrot.description: The Turquoise Parrot is endemic to southeastern Australia.
Turquoise Parrot.plumage: Mainly green with turquoise blue on the wings, rump, and tail.

Orange-fronted Parakeet.description: The Orange-fronted Parakeet is found in Mexico and parts of Central America.
Orange-fronted Parakeet.plumage: Mainly green with an orange forehead and crown.

Red-crowned Parakeet.description: The Red-crowned Parakeet is native to New Zealand, particularly in forested areas.
Red-crowned Parakeet.plumage: Mainly green with a red crown, blue wings, and yellow underparts.

Sulphur-crested Parakeet.description: The Sulphur-crested Parakeet is native to New Guinea and parts of Australia.
Sulphur-crested Parakeet.plumage: Mainly white with yellow crests and patches on the cheeks.

Blue-crowned Hanging Parrot.description: The Blue-crowned Hanging Parrot is found in forests and woodlands across Southeast Asia.
Blue-crowned Hanging Parrot.plumage: Mainly green with a blue crown and red beak.

Scarlet-chested Parakeet.description: The Scarlet-chested Parakeet, also known as the Splendid Parrot, is native to central Australia.
Scarlet-chested Parakeet.plumage: Mainly green with a scarlet chest, blue wings, and yellow belly.

Maroon-bellied Parakeet.description: The Maroon-bellied Parakeet is native to forests of eastern Brazil.
Maroon-bellied Parakeet.plumage: Mainly green with a maroon-colored belly and blue wing feathers.

Black-winged Lovebird.description: The Black-winged Lovebird is native to the highlands of Ethiopia.
Black-winged Lovebird.plumage: Mainly green with black wings, red beak, and white eye ring.

Yellow-collared Lovebird.description: The Yellow-collared Lovebird is native to northern Tanzania.
Yellow-collared Lovebird.plumage: Mainly green with a yellow collar and orange face.

Violet Turaco.description: The Violet Turaco, also known as the Violaceous Plantain-eater, is native to the forests of West Africa.
Violet Turaco.plumage: Mainly violet with red underwings, green back, and yellow beak.

Blue-crowned Parakeet.description: The Blue-crowned Parakeet is native to South America, particularly in Argentina and Paraguay.
Blue-crowned Parakeet.plumage: Mainly green with a blue crown and red-orange belly.

Jenday Conure.description: The Jenday Conure is native to northeastern Brazil.
Jenday Conure.plumage: Mainly green with yellow head, orange cheeks, and blue wings.

Blue-headed Parrot.description: The Blue-headed Parrot is native to South America, particularly in the Amazon basin.
Blue-headed Parrot.plumage: Mainly green with a blue head, red undertail coverts, and maroon shoulder patches.

Red-fan Parrot.description: The Red-fan Parrot, also known as the Hawk-headed Parrot, is native to the Amazon rainforest.
Red-fan Parrot.plumage: Mainly green with a red or maroon fan-shaped crest and blue facial skin.

Gouldian Finch.description: The Gouldian Finch, also known as the Rainbow Finch, is native to northern Australia.
Gouldian Finch.plumage: Distinctive multicolored plumage with red, black, yellow, and green variations.

Eastern Rosella.description: The Eastern Rosella is native to southeastern Australia.
Eastern Rosella.plumage: Mainly red with white cheeks, blue patches on wings, and yellow underparts.

Green-naped Lorikeet.description: The Green-naped Lorikeet is found in forests and woodlands of Indonesia and New Guinea.
Green-naped Lorikeet.plumage: Mainly green with a red beak and blue nape.

Red-whiskered Bulbul.description: The Red-whiskered Bulbul is native to Asia, particularly in India and Sri Lanka.
Red-whiskered Bulbul.plumage: Brown upperparts, white underparts, red face patch, and black crest.

Blue-gray Tanager.description: The Blue-gray Tanager is found in forests and gardens of South America.

Rainbow Lorikeet.description: The Rainbow Lorikeet is native to Australia and is known for its vibrant plumage and playful behavior.
Rainbow Lorikeet.plumage: Mainly green with a rainbow of colors on its head, chest, and wings.

Scarlet Macaw.description: The Scarlet Macaw is one of the most iconic parrots, known for its brilliant red, yellow, and blue plumage.
Scarlet Macaw.plumage: Vibrant red, yellow, and blue with a white face patch.

Cockatiel.description: The Cockatiel is a small, crested parrot native to Australia and prized for its friendly disposition and whistling abilities.
Cockatiel.plumage: Gray body with yellow face and crest markings.

Crimson Rosella.description: The Crimson Rosella is a colorful parrot native to eastern and southeastern Australia.
Crimson Rosella.plumage: Mainly red with blue cheeks, white patches on wings, and black tail feathers.

Eclectus Parrot.description: The Eclectus Parrot is known for its striking sexual dimorphism, with males having bright green plumage and females having red and purple plumage.
Eclectus Parrot.plumage: Male: Bright green. Female: Red and purple.
